intro: Antirrhinum album, commonly known as the common toadflax, is a flowering plant native to Europe, western Asia, and North Africa. It is characterized by its distinctive two-lipped, tubular flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces erect, branching stems covered in fine hairs. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often hairy, while the flowers are borne in clusters at the ends of the stems. Antirrhinum album is often found in meadows, grasslands, and along roadsides, thriving in well-drained soils.
